metadata.title: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome  Occupational Therapy
synonyms: systemic exertion intolerance disease: occupational therapy
anatomical location body part affected: Unknown, although symptoms are often triggered by infections/multiple systems are affected by fatigue
description: Chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS), also known as myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS), is “a serious, chronic, complex, systemic disease that can often profoundly affect the lives of patients”(1)
Marked by profound fatigue, cognitive impairment, sleeping difficulties, autonomic symptoms, and pain which are made worse with any type of exertion(1)

The Institute of Medicine (IOM) released an expert committee report of the evidence base for ME/CFS, the following key facts were identified:(1) –ME/CFS affects 836,000 to 2.5 million Americans -This is likely a very low estimate of prevalence, as it is estimated that in 84–91%  of persons with the condition ME/CFS has not been diagnosed –There are five main symptoms of ME/CFS. See “Presentation/signs and symptoms” section for details –The economic burden resulting from loss of productivity in patients with ME/CFS and high medical costs is $17 billion to $24 billion annually in the United States –At least one quarter of ME/CFS patients are bed- or house-bound  at some point during their illness –The IOM recommended that the name “systemic exertion intolerance disease” (SEID) replace both ME/CFS and CFS, as this name reflects the central characteristic of the disease: exertion intolerance with systemic effects -The term chronic fatigue syndrome has been found to negatively affect patients’, as well as others’ (medical personnel, family members, colleagues), perceptions of the illness. It is also felt to trivialize the seriousness of the disease and promote misunderstanding -Myalgic encephalomyelitis is not an appropriate name, as the evidence is lacking to prove that brain inflammation (encephalomyelitis) is part of the disease and also because myalgia is a minor symptom -For the purpose of this Clinical Review, CFS will be referred to as ME/CFS (SEID) –The IOM suggests that many healthcare providers are skeptical about ME/CFS (SEID) and think it is solely a mental health condition. They stress that it is a serious illness that requires timely diagnosis and appropriate care

Prior to the IOM report, the following description of ME/CFS (SEID) was utilized by the CDC:(2,3)  –“A condition characterized by profound mental and physical exhaustion, with at least 6 months’ presence of multiple systemic and neuropsychiatric symptoms, and at least 4 of 8 associated conditions are required: -Impaired memory -Sore throat -Tender lymph nodes -Persistent muscle or joint pain -New headaches -Non-refreshing  sleep -Post-exertional  malaise > 24 hours”
ME/CFS (SEID) occurs mainly in adults,but the CDC reports that 0.2–2.3%  of children and adolescents have ME/CFS (SEID)with the prevalence higher in adolescents(4,27)

Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and graded exercise therapy together are the cornerstone of treatment(2,3,5) –CBT should be individualized and focus on challenging fatigue-related  cognitions and planning social and occupational rehabilitation –Graded exercise involves determining what the patient can do without exacerbating symptoms and gradually increasing intensity and duration -Fear of movement and avoidance of physical activity is common in ME/CFS (SEID)

Occupational therapy interventions in the treatment of ME/CFS (SEID) include the following:(6) –CBT – provided by health professionals (usually either psychologists or occupational therapists [OTs]) who have received training in CBT –Energy conservation techniques – either focused on the individual or on adapting the task and/or environment. These can also include assistive and adaptive equipment as well as time management, pacing skills, and prioritizing occupations –Consultation -Working with patients to identify alternative and potentially new occupations -Providing referrals to community resources -Education for patient and family on ME/CFS (SEID), as well as strategies for how to self-advocate  given occupational changes

ICD-10 codes.R53.82: chronic fatigue, unspecified (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference and not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified

Patients in the United States who have ME/CFS (SEID) and cannot work can apply for disability through the Social Security Administration.(4)An ME/CFS (SEID)-related  fact sheet for healthcare professionals, “Providing Medical Evidence for Individuals with Chronic Fatigue Syndrome – Fact Sheet” is available at https://www.ssa.gov/disability/professionals/documents/64-063.pdf
presentation signs and symptoms: There are five main symptoms of ME/CFS (SEID). For diagnosis, the first three must be present, plus one or both of the last two(1) –Substantial reduction or impairment in ability to carry out pre-illness  levels of occupational, educational, social, or personal activities that persists for more than 6 months, that is accompanied by profound fatigue. It must be of new or definite onset (not lifelong), not the result of ongoing excessive exertion, and is not substantially alleviated by rest –Worsening of symptoms after physical, cognitive, or emotional effort (i.e., post-exertional  malaise) –Unrefreshing sleep –Cognitive impairment –Orthostatic intolerance
Other common symptoms are pain, failure to recover from prior infection, and abnormal immune function(1)
Sudden onset of fatigue after relatively common illness or other stressor(2)
Joint and muscle aching with no physical evidence of inflammation(2)
Diffuse aching not localized to joints or muscles, but no erythema, effusion, or limitation of motion(2)
Muscles that fatigue quickly, but are of normal strength(2)
contraindications precautions to test: Stop examination if patient shows signs of worsening symptoms (e.g., orthostatic intolerance, pain)

Plan on extra time for the examination; allow for frequent rest breaks between tests or spread it out over multiple sessions –Allowing the person to tell his or her own story is part of the lifestyle management program proposed by Cox(7)
Use the examination to gain insight into the patient’s endurance capacity over an extended period of time(6)
It is important that the patient’s pain be respected and, for the examination, to be modified accordingly
The focus of the evaluation should be on what the client wants, needs, or is expected to do during occupational performance(6)

causes: The cause of ME/CFE (SEID) is unknown, although symptoms might be triggered by certain infections(1)
An occult retrovirus infection or an immune dysregulation mechanism has been suggested, but studies have failed to showthese as causes(1,5)

The cause is considered to be multifactorial,possibly resulting from the interaction of genetic predisposition, environmentalfactors, an initiating stressor, and perpetuating factors(3)–Physiological or environmental stressor could precipitate disease–Major stressor often noted in months prior to beginning of symptoms
pathogenesis: Once symptoms present, they are hypothesized to contribute to an altered physiology in the neuroendocrine, immune,neuromuscular, autonomic, and serotonergic systems(3)
There have been findings that suggest a link between ME/CFS (SEID) and certain genes that mediate immune and stressresponses(2)
risk factors: Average age of onset is 33, but the condition has been reported in patients younger than 10 and older than age 70(1)
Childhood trauma, emotional instability, and/or self-reported stress(5)

Lifestyle(3)–Childhood inactivity or overactivity–Inactivity in adulthood after infectious mononucleosis–Comorbid mood disorders of depression and anxiety–Following infection with Ross River virus, Coxiella burnetii , Giardia lamblia

overall contraindications precautions: Proceed slowly with evaluation and treatment, as exacerbation of symptoms can occur with any unaccustomed exertion
Monitor patient closely during any exertion for any atypical responses, such as orthostatic intolerance or abnormal heart response

Believing that the patient is truly symptomatic is important to the examination and treatment process. ME/CFS (SEID) patients are often sensitive to validity of their symptoms and often have experienced frustration, anger, and depression brought on by family and colleagues doubting the validity of their disease(2)
Be aware of the many comorbidities that occur with ME/CFS (SEID) (listed below)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: ME/CFS (SEID) has a discrete onset.(3)When was ME/CFS (SEID) first diagnosed? What is the reason for occupational therapy referral?Has the patient had any previous infections prior to onset of symptoms?

course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Are they perceived to be effective by the patient? There are no established pharmacologic treatments for ME/CFS (SEID)(3) It is advised not to prescribe antimicrobials, corticosteroids, or antidepressants, as they have not been proven to be of any benefit(2)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:(3)
No single diagnostic test is available for ME/CFS (SEID)
Standard laboratory tests to rule out other causes of symptoms

Additional studies if suggestive or client at risk: Antinuclear antibodies and rheumatoid factor, creatinine kinase, tuberculin skin test, serum cortisol, HIV , venereal disease tests, Lyme serology, IgA tissue transglutaminase
No imaging tests are routine, but an EEG and/or MRI might be done if CNS symptoms are present
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help or not Ask about possible home remedies (e.g., special diets, vitamin treatments) as these are common, unstudied, and often expensive or potentially dangerous(2) Discuss complementary therapies that are not dangerous, such as acupuncture, openly with patient so that the clinicianpatient  relationship is maintained(2) A systematic review and meta-analysis  on the effects of acupuncture and moxibustion (Chinese medicine involving burning dried mugwort on or near the skin) in ME/CFS included 31 studies, all conducted in China, with a total of 2,225 subjects. Authors of the review found that combined acupuncture and moxibustion was the most effective and that acupuncture or moxibustion in isolation was more effective than sham treatments, Chinese herbal medicine, and “Western medicine.” However, review authors noted that these results could be due to the placebo effect. Overall, the quality of the research is low and additional, goodquality  RCTs are needed to draw firm conclusions(8) In two systematic reviews on dietary and nutritional interventions for ME/CFS (SEID) published in 2017 (one that included 17 studies and one that included 22 studies), researchers found that most studies had methodological limitations and generally lowquality  evidence for the effectiveness of any given diet or supplement. Because the evidence for elimination diets and nutritional supplements is insufficient, authors recommended a balanced diet to support the health of individuals with ME/CFS (SEID)(24,29)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased) -Fatigue in ME/CFS (SEID) is profound, not the result of ongoing excessive exertion, and not substantially alleviated by rest(1) -Exposure to physical or cognitive stressors aggravates the patient’s symptoms (post-exertional malaise) -Pain is a common complaint but highly variable in presence, nature, and severity(1) -Pain with ME/CFS (SEID) can take many forms, including headaches, arthralgia, and myalgia -Ask whether patient has orthostatic symptoms when assuming an upright posture
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of various symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, worst, and at the moment (specifically address levels of fatigue and if pain is present now and how much )
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also, document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night -ME/CFS (SEID) patients complain of unrefreshing sleep. Other sleep disorders might be present and the diagnosis of a primary sleep disorder does not rule out the diagnosis of ME/CFS (SEID)(1) -A non-addicting  sleep aid might be beneficial if insomnia is present.(3) Encourage the patient to discuss this with his/her physician as appropriate
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, headaches, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document the use of supplemental oxygen -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________ -Slowed information processing is common in patients with ME/CFS (SEID)(1)

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document periods of excessive fatigue in the past
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders(3) Fibromyalgia Irritable bowel syndrome Temporomandibular joint disorder Anxiety disorders Major depression PTSD Domestic violence ADHD Postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: -Ask about pre-illness  levels of occupational, educational, social,and personal activities. For diagnosis of ME/CFS (SEID), patient must have substantial reduction or impairment in the ability to engage in these activities that has persisted for more than 6 months(1)
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document any daily activities that the client is either limited in doing or requires assistance. Document the use of any adaptive equipment
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members). What are the patient’s role functions at home? Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? Has a home safety check been performed at the patient’s home?  -Suggested occupation-focused  assessments(6) -NIH Activity Record -Role Checklist -Occupational Performance History Interview II -Assessment of Motor and Process Skills -Occupational Self-Assessment,  version 2.2 -Performance Assessment of Self-care  Skills (PASS) -Canadian Occupational Performance Measure (COPM) -Short Form-36  (SF-36)

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess appropriateness and safety of any assistive and adaptive devices currently being used, if applicable –The use of assistive and adaptive devices can be important to energy-conservation  techniques as the patient adapts to tasks and the environment(6)
relevant tests and measures.balance: Evaluate static and dynamic balance during functional tasks. The Tinetti or Berg Balance Scales can be utilized. Be aware of any orthostatic intolerance (see description below)
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Assess heart rate, blood pressure, and respiratory rate regularly pre/during/post activity; use Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale if indicated

Orthostatic intolerance (i.e., worsening of symptoms upon assuming and maintaining upright posture) is common in patients with ME/CFS (SEID). Monitor closely heart rate and blood pressure as well as other symptoms (lightheadedness) during standing activities •Ergonomics/body mechanics: Assess proper body mechanics with functional mobility to assist in energy-conservation techniques •Functional mobility  (including transfers, etc.): Assess bed mobility and transfers to determine the amount of assistance needed for the patient to perform each activity. Be sensitive to complaints or observations of fatigue and allow patient to rest as needed. The Timed Up and Go (TUG) test, FIM test, or SF-36  may be administered
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Observe patient’s gait and ability to climb stairs (assisted or unassisted)Assess and document joint integrity, stability, mobility, and deformity
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess using manual muscle testing (MMT) or by observing functional movement –A symptom of ME/CFS (SEID) can be muscles that fatigue quickly but appear normal in strength(2)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess posture in sitting, standing and during functional activities
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Screen for functional ROM of trunk and extremities during the prescribed exercises
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess deep tendon reflexes, if applicable Assess safety and ability to perform ADLs hair, upper and lower body dressing, clothing management, using the toilet, applying makeup or shaving the face, bathing, eating –The FIM, the Assessment of Motor and Process Skills (AMPS), the Kohlman Evaluation of Living Skills (KELS), the Disability Rating Index (DRI), the Klein-Bell  Activities of Daily Living Scale (Klein-Bell),  the Performance and Satisfaction in Activities of Daily Living (PS-ADL),  and the Barthel Activities of Daily Living Index are appropriate standardized measures for ADLs in patients with ME/CFS (SEID) –For high-functioning  patients, assess IADLs such as driving (including car transfers), meal preparation, shopping, and housework(1) -Adults -Work and Social Adjustment Scale -SF-36 -The Lawton Instrumental Activities of Daily Living (IADL) Scale -Katz Index of Independence in Activities of Daily Living -Children -Short form of the Child Health Questionnaire -Pediatrics Quality of Life Inventory -Functional Disability Inventory (FDI)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: General sensory testing includes light touch, pain, temperature, tactile localization, two-point discrimination, if applicable
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: –Chronic fatigue syndrome – activities and participation questionnaire (CFS-APQ) -In multiple systematic reviews of the measurement instruments to evaluate activity limitation and participation restrictions in patients with ME/CFS (SEID), investigators found that no measurement instrument sufficiently evaluated activity limitation and participation restrictions but suggested that, if it is necessary to use a measurement instrument, the CFS-APQ  is a disease-specific  instrument with moderate content and construct validity(9,28) -Two additional self-reporting  measurements identified by authors of a systematic review of measurements for physical activity in patients with ME/CFS (SEID) are the Activity Pattern Interview (API) and the International Physical Activity Questionnaire–Short Form (IPAQ-SF).  Neither instrument was considered the gold standard; however, they were both adequate for measuring physical activity level in the ME/CFS (SEID) population(28) –Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Screening Questionnaire(10) -Assesses sociodemographic characteristics and the presence versus absence of ME/CFS (SEID) symptoms –Activity Pacing Questionnaire (APQ-26)(23)activity adjustment, activity consistency, activity progression, activity planning, and activity acceptance -Questionnaire was validated in a self-report  study conducted in England in which researchers found it to have good internal consistency, test-retest reliability, and construct validity based on the subgroup of eligible participants who participated in the study
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, cognition  (including memory, problem solving) –Note patient’s ability to communicate and level of arousal as well as memory, attention, problem solving, and orientation to person, place, time, and situation –Patients with ME/CFS (SEID) have problems with thinking or executive function that are exacerbated by exertion, effort, or stress or time pressure(1) -Slowed information processing might play a central role in memory impairments, attention deficits, and impaired psychomotor function. These cognitive impairments are often responsible for the disability that results in loss of employment(1)//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1739950/pdf/v057p00353.pdf//www.cdc.gov/me-cfs/pdfs/wichita-data-access/symptom-inventory-doc.pdf//www.goodmedicine.org.uk/files/assessment,%20chalder%20fatigue%20scale.pdf

contraindications precautions.general: Patients with this diagnosis may be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Fatigue, difficulty with ADLs or IADLs, reduced physical activity due to fear of fatigue, difficulty pacing ADLs, negative attitude displayed by patient or family towards diagnosis, unrealistic expectations regarding activity, patient desire to have some control and a positive outlook with the disease
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out  (3) Idiopathic chronic fatigue  Psychiatric disorders – major depression, somatization disorder Physiologic fatigue (inadequate or disrupted sleep, menopause) Pregnancy, until 3 months postpartum Insomnia Endocrine disorders – hypothyroidism, Addison disease, Cushing syndrome,diabetes Localized infection Chronic or subacute bacterial disease (e.g., endocarditis) Lyme disease Fungal disease Parasitic disease HIV or related disease Iatrogenic conditions (e.g., due to medications) Toxic agent exposure Morbid obesity (BMI > 40) Malignancy Autoimmune disease Chronic inflammatory disease Neuromuscular disease (e.g., multiple sclerosis, myasthenia gravis)
prognosis: Prognosis for ME/CFS (SEID) is fair;symptoms of as the disease fluctuate but rarely resolve completely(2)

Poorer prognosis associated with age > 38 years, more than 8 symptoms, duration over 1.5 years, less than 16 years of formal education, a history of a dysthymic disorder, and the belief that the disease is due to a physical cause(2)
Complications of ME/CFS (SEID) include depression, unemployment, being disabled (according to SSA), polypharmacy, increased risk of non-Hodgkin  lymphoma in older adult ME/CFS (SEID) patients(3)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Sleep specialist for sleep disturbance Pain specialist for prominent, chronic pain Psychiatrist for assistance in any comorbid mental disorders
other considerations: Believing that the patient is truly symptomatic is important to the examination and treatment process. ME/CFS (SEID) patients are often sensitive to validity of their symptoms and often experience frustration, anger, and depression brought on by family and colleagues doubting the validity of their disease(2)

Authors of a study conducted in the United States of the effects of coping styles on occupational participation in adults with ME/CFS (SEID) suggest that a coping style of maintaining activity is positively associated with occupational participation, whereas a coping style of illness accommodation is negatively associated with occupational participation(11)

Researchers of a qualitative study conducted in Australia of the illness experiences of five patients with ME/CFS (SEID), utilizing the Occupational Performance History Interview–II  (OPHI-II),  noted the following themes:(12) –Experiencing and understanding ME/CFS (SEID) – includes dealing with associated uncertainty and skepticism –Experiencing different types of fatigue – physical fatigue, mental fatigue, and fatigue related to being able to cope with others or the environment –“An ending and a beginning” – acknowledging their former life, grieving for what was lost, finding ways to maintain sense of self with diagnosis –Experiencing doing activities – dealing with restriction of activities, changing expectations of activities, acknowledging fluctuations day-to-day  in their abilities to do activities, getting “out of the habit” of doing daily activities –Doing something towards getting well – consistently attempting to do activities, using rest and relaxation, maintaining a positive outlook

ME/CFS (SEID) in young persons –Young persons (12–18  years old) who developed ME/CFS (SEID) after glandular fever reported lower perceived competency and reduced physical functioning, school performance, social activities, emotional functioning, and general health when compared to young persons who had glandular fever but did not develop ME/CFS (SEID).This outcome is  supported by the Model of Human Occupation (MOHO), which asserts that impairments affect volition and quality of life(13) -Three hundred one young persons with glandular fever were followed in this study conducted in the United States. Six months later, 39 met the criteria for ME/CFS (SEID) and were randomly matched with 39 who had fully recovered. Both groups were evaluated at 12 months and 24 months post infection –Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Screening Questionnaire was utilized for diagnosis. Outcome measures were Occupational Self-Assessment  and Child Health Questionnaire
treatment summary: CBT and graded exercise therapy (GET) together are considered the cornerstone of ME/CFS (SEID) treatment(2,3,5) –CBT and GET can be added safely to specialist medical care (SMC) and will moderately improve symptoms of ME/CFS (SEID)(14) -Based on a parallel-group,  randomized trial of 641 patients with ME/CFS (SEID) conducted in the United Kingdom -The study compared adaptive pacing therapy (APT), CBT, and GET to SMC-alone -The goal of CBT is to help the patient change thinking and behavioral patterns that lead to negative outcomes -GET involves therapeutic exercise that begins very slowly at a light level of intensity and is gradually increased over time as the patient gains strength and endurance -Outcome measures were Chalder fatigue scale to measure fatigue, Short Form-36  to measure function, and the recording of adverse events to evaluate safety

Authors of a Cochrane review examining the effectiveness and acceptability of CBT for ME/CFS (SEID) concluded that CBT was better than usual care and might be better than other psychological therapies. However, there was a lack of evidence when comparing CBT alone or in combination with other treatments(15) –Based on 15 studies involving 1,043 patients with ME/CFS (SEID) –Authors concluded that future studies are required for the development of effective treatment programs

Authors of a Cochrane review examining the effectiveness of GET compared to other interventions for patients with ME/ CFS (SEID) concluded that patients feel less fatigued after exercise therapy. There also appear to be benefits for sleep, physical function, and self-perceived  general health, but no conclusions could be made about pain, quality of life, anxiety, depression, or drop-out rate(16) –Based on eight RCTs involving 1,518 patients –The authors also concluded that GET appeared more effective than pacing but had similar results as CBT –Further RCTs are required to investigate the most beneficial type, duration, and intensity of exercise intervention

In an exploratory pilot study conducted in Germany, researchers compared the effects of heart-rate  variability biofeedback to GET on fatigue severity in 28 women with ME/CFS (SEID). Each woman in the group was randomly assigned to participate in eight sessions of either heart-rate  variability biofeedback or GET. With heart-rate variability biofeedback, patients learn techniques such as breathing and positive thinking to control the wave form that represents their heart rate. Fatigue severity significantly improved for both groups. In the heart-rate  variability biofeedback group, cognitive aspects of fatigue (depression and mental quality of life) improved significantly, while physical aspects of fatigue (physical quality of life) improved significantly for the GET group(26)
For detailed information on ME/CFS (SEID) and exercise, see Clinical Review…Chronic Fatigue Syndrome and Exercise ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709160

Activity pacing self-management  (APSM) appears to be feasible and helpful when trying to optimize participation in ADLs in women with ME/CFS (SEID)(17) –Based on an RCT conducted in Belgium in which 33 women with ME/CFS (SEID) were randomly assigned to either an APSM group or a relaxation group. Both groups received individual therapy sessions of 60–90  min/week for 3 consecutive weeks –The APSM intervention was based on a stabilization phase and a grading phase -During the stabilization phase, patients were coached on how to perform ADLs within limits of their actual capacity. Activity duration was 20–50%  lower than reported self-capacity  to account for overestimation by patients and each activity block was interspersed with breaks. Once clients could control ADLs without excessive feelings of fatigue, they entered the grading phase -During the grading phase, activity and exercise were increased gradually, based on relevant and achievable personal goals  –The relaxation group included education about the role of stress in ME/CFS (SEID), an evidence-based  information booklet, instruction in various stress reduction skills (Jacobson relaxation, Schultz relaxation, visualization, etc.), and completion of a stress reaction diary, which was discussed with the therapist –Outcome measures were the COPM (for performance of and satisfaction with desired ADLs) and CIS (to measure fatigue). COPM improved significantly in both groups, but only the APSM group had significant differences in satisfaction scores and in CIS

Although it is evident that ME/CFS (SEID) causes occupational disruption, general practitioners do not seem to be able to provide the care that is required, whereas OTs might be able to.(12,18,19,20) However, the evidence for OT involvement up to this point has been tertiary care and anecdotal advice(18) –Burley et al. reported a case study of a woman in England who had been severely affected by ME/CFS (SEID) for 8 years and had been bedbound for 3 years but was successfully treated by an inpatient OT program (lifestyle management program)(21) -Patient started program intolerant to light, noise, and visitors, completely dependent for ADLs, unable to sit up to eat, and had an abnormal sleep pattern -Elements of the OT lifestyle management program include(7) -history taking that allows person to tell his or her own story -exploration of ADLs, taking into effect performance, disruption, and adaptation -helping the patient to understand rest and relaxation -helping patient to understand concept of graded activity and exercise -energy conservation strategies -reintroduction of activity over time, including prioritizing -establishing balance (rest and activity, wants and needs, work and leisure, mental and physical tasks) -the impact and readjustment of sleep patterns -how feelings affect occupational performance and balance -strategies for coping with others and change -discharge planning -involvement of family and friends -Patient was discharged independently bathing, dressing, and grooming, walking to toilet, going shopping once a week in wheelchair, having visitors regularly, making cards and photo frames, and beginning to take control of her finances –An integrative, consumer-driven  rehabilitation program focused on improving quality of life and reducing symptom severity was found to be moderately effective in an RCT conducted in the United States(10) -Forty-seven  patients with ME/CFS (SEID) were randomly assigned to either an immediate program or a delayed program control group -Program used participatory action research (i.e., patients take active role in designing and conducting research) and empowerment theory (i.e., in which is taught self-reliance  and reliance on peers for solving problems) -Program consisted of 2-hour  biweekly meetings over 4 months, followed by 7 months of peer counseling -Biweekly meetings were led by OT and peer counselor and consisted of individual check-ins and reporting of self-monitored  goal attainments, followed by educational lectures and discussions of self-selected  topics relevant to ME/CFS (SEID) -Examples of topics include envelope theory, cognitive coping skills training, relaxation, employment issues, personal relationships, and traditional and complementary medical approaches -Peer counseling included self-advocacy training, continued monitoring of goals, and case coordination -Outcome measures were Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Symptom Rating Scale and the Quality of Life Index –Principles of the MOHO have been applied as a way to understand the relationships between volition, habituation, performance capacities, and the environment as they influence individuals with ME/CFS (SEID)(20) -The same authors reviewed the literature on work-related  impairment and called for the development of comprehensive rehabilitation programs that focus on the volitional, functional, social, and environmental aspects of re-employment(22)

In an RCT conducted in Norway, researchers found that a self-management  program conducted in a group setting was no more effective than traditional care for improving symptoms of ME/CFS (SEID) in adults(25) . decreased complaints of fatigue: CIS, Chalder Fatigue Scale, CDC Symptom Inventory for CFS, Wood Mental Fatigue Inventory
improved adls: Work and Social Adjustment Scale, the Lawton Instrumental Activities of Daily Living (IADL) Scale, Katz Index ofIndependence in Activities of Daily Living, FIM, Barthel Activities of Daily Living Index
improved occupational performance: NIH Activity Record, Role Checklist, Occupational Performance History Interview II, Assessment of Motor andProcess Skills, Occupational Self-assessment,  version 2.2, Performance Assessment of Self-care Skills (PASS), CanadianOccupational Performance Measure (COPM), Short Form-36  (SF-36)

maintenance or prevention: Patients with ME/CFS (SEID) should be encouraged to remain as active as possible, as coping by maintaining physical activity is associated positively with occupational performance(11)
As there is no identified cause of ME/CFS (SEID), there is currently no known way to prevent it(4)
